facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 38 of 1953 filed under Article 132(1) of the Constitution from Madras High Court Judgment dated 13th December 1951 in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2591 of 1951.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 38 of 1953. Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 13th December, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature, Madras, in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2591 of 1951.

facts.text: Madras High Court allowed petition under Article 226 and directed writ of prohibition against appellant prohibiting settlement of scheme for Shirur Math.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is directed against a judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court, dated the 13th of December, 1951, by which the learned Judges allowed petition, presented by the respondent under article 226 of the Constitution, and directed a writ of prohibition to issue in his favour prohibiting the appellant from proceeding with the settlement of a scheme in companynection with a Math, known as the Shirur Math, of which the petitioner happens to be the head or superior.

facts.text: Petition filed when Madras Hindu Religious Endowments Act II of 1927 was in force against Hindu Religious Endowments Board under that Act.

anchor.surface_text: It may be stated at the outset that the petition was filed at a time when the Madras Hindu Religion Endowments Act  Act II of 1927 , was in force and the writ was prayed for against the Hindu Religious Endowments Board companystituted under that Act, which -was the predecessor in authority of the present appellant and had initiated proceedings for settlement of a scheme against the petitioner under section 61 of the said Act.

facts.text: Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 came into force on 27th August 1951.

anchor.surface_text: While the petitions were still pending, the Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act,, 1951  hereinafter called the New Act , was passed by the Madras Legislature and came into force on the 27th of August, 1951.

facts.text: Shirur Math is one of eight Maths at Udipi, South Kanara district, founded by Shri Madhwacharya.

anchor.surface_text: The Math, known as Shirur Math, of which the petitioner is the superior or Mathadhipati, is one of the eight Maths situated at Udipi in the district of South Kanara and they are reputed to have been founded by Shri Madhwacharya, the well-known exponent of dualistic theism in the Hindu Religion.

facts.text: Petitioner installed as Mathadhipati in 1919 as minor, assumed management in 1926.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was installed as Mathadhipati in the year 1919, when he was still a minor, and he assumed management after companying of age some time in 1926.

facts.text: Math heavily in debt in 1926, cleared large portion by 1930, debts incurred in 1931 for Pariyayam.

anchor.surface_text: At that time the Math was heavily in debt. Between 1926 and 1930 the Swami succeeded in clearing off a large portion of the debt. In 1931, however, came the 1009 turn of his taking over management of the Shri Krishna Math and he had had to incur debts to meet the heavy expenditure attendant on the Pariyayam ceremonies,

facts.text: Debts mounted to nearly a lakh of rupees in 1946 due to second Pariyayam amid scarcity.

anchor.surface_text: but troubles again arose in 1946, which was the year of the second Pariyayam of the Swami. Owing to scarcity and the high prices of companymodities at that time, the Swami had to borrow money to meet the expenditure and the debts mounted up to nearly a lakh of rupees.

facts.text: Hindu Religious Endowments Board under 1927 Act called upon Swami to appoint competent manager under section 61A.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindu Religious Endowments Board, functioning under the Earlier Act of 1927, intervened at this stage and in exercise of its powers under section 61 -A of the Act called upon the Swami to appoint a companypetent manager to manage the affairs of the institution.

facts.text: Sripath Achar appointed agent, Power of Attorney executed on 24th December 1948.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in pursuance of the direction of the Board, one Sripath Achar was appointed an agent and a Power of Attorney was executed in his favour on the 24th of December, 1948.

facts.text: Swami served notice terminating agency on 26th September 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In this state of affairs the Swami,, on the 26th of September, 1950, served a numberice upon the agent terminating his agency and calling upon him to hand over to the Mathadhipati all account papers and vouchers relating to the institution together with the cash in hand.

facts.text: Petitioner filed suit against agent on 4th October 1950 in Sub Court South Kanara for accounts, injunction.

anchor.surface_text: On the 4th of October, 1950, the petitioner filed a suit against the agent in the Sub,Court of South Kanara for recovery of the account books and other articles belonging to the Math, for rendering an account of the management and also for an injunction restraining the said agent from interfering with the affairs of the Math under companyour of the 1010 authority companyferred by the Power of Attorney which the plaintiff had cancelled.

facts.text: Agent filed application to Board on 3rd October 1950 complaining against cancellation.

anchor.surface_text: The said Sripath Achar anticipating this suit filed an application to the Board on the 3rd of October, 1950, companyplaining against the cancellation of the Power of Attorney and his management of the Math.

facts.text: Board issued notice on 4th October 1950 for inquiry on 24th October 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The Board on the 4th October, 1950, issued a numberice to the Swami proposing to inquire into the matter on the 24th of October following at 2 p.m. at Madras and requesting the Swami either to apppear in person or by a pleader.

facts.text: Swami replied on 21st October 1950 that matter sub judice.

anchor.surface_text: To this the Swami sent a reply on 21st October, 1950, stating that the subject-matter of the very enquiry was before the companyrt in the original suit filed by him and as the matter was sub judice the enquiry should be put off.

facts.text: Board initiated suo moto proceedings under section 62 on 6th November 1950 for scheme.

anchor.surface_text: The Board, it appears, dropped that enquiry, but without waiting for the result of the suit, initiated proceedings suo moto under section 62 of the Earlier Act and issued a numberice upon the Swami on the 6th of November, 1950, stating that it had reason to believe that the endowments of the said Math were being mismanaged and that a scheme should be framed for the administration of its affairs.

facts.text: High Court petition filed on 12th February 1951.

anchor.surface_text: On the 12th of February, 1951, the peti- tioner filed the petition, out of which this appeal arises, in the High Court of Madras, praying for a writ of prohibition to prohibit the Board from taking further steps in the matter of settling a scheme for the administration of the Math.

facts.text: High Court held Board's action perverse exercise of jurisdiction on merits.

anchor.surface_text: On the merits, it was held that in the circumstances of the case the action of the Board was a perverse exercise of its jurisdiction and that it should 1012 number be allowed to proceed in regard to the settlement of the scheme.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal on certificate under Article 132(1), appellant confined to constitutional points.

anchor.surface_text: The Commisioner has number companye up on appeal before us on the strength of a certificate granted by the High Court under article 132 1  of the Constitution. The learned Advocate-General for Madras, who appeared in support of the appeal, companyfined his arguments exclusively to the companystitutional points involved in this case.

facts.text: Mathadhipati holds beneficial interest in Math property, blending office and property rights.

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the companyception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other.

This appeal is directed against a judgment of a Division Bench of the Madras High Court, dated the 13th of December, 1951, by which the learned Judges allowed petition, presented by the respondent under article 226 of the Constitution, and directed a writ of prohibition to issue in his favour prohibiting the appellant from proceeding with the settlement of a scheme in connection with a Math, known as the Shirur Math, of which the petitioner happens to be the head or superior.

Appeal under article 132 1  of the Constitution of India from the Judgment and Order dated the 13th December, 1951, of the High Court of Judicature, Madras, in Civil Miscellaneous Petition No. 2591 of 1951.

issues.text: whether the law regulating the framing of a scheme interfering with the management of the Math and its affairs by the Mathadhipati conflicted with the provisions of articles 19(1)(f) and 26 of the Constitution and was hence void under article 13

anchor.surface_text: The main contention, however, was that having regard to the fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution in matters of religion and religious institutions belonging to particular religious denominations, the law regulating the framing of a scheme interfering with the management of the Math and its affairs by the Mathadhipati conflicted with the provisions of art- icles 19 1   f  and 26 of the Constitution and was hence void under article 13.

issues.text: whether the provisions of the Act were discriminatory in their character and offended against article 15 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged further that the provisions of the Act were discriminatory in their character and offended against article 15 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the respondent as Mathadhipati has a right to property in the legal sense in the religious institution and its endowments which would enable him to claim the protection of article 19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: As regards article 19 1 f of the Constitution, the question that requires consideration is, whether the respondent as Mathadhipati has a right to property in the legal sense,, in the religious institution and its endowments which would enable him to claim the -protection of this article ?

issues.text: whether article 19(1)(f) deals with concrete rights of property at all

anchor.surface_text: A question is also formulated as to whether this article deals with concrete rights of property at all ?

issues.text: whether article 25 which is intended to protect religious freedom only so far as individuals are concerned, can be invoked in favour of an institution or Organisation

anchor.surface_text: So far as article 25 of the Constitution is concerned, the point raised is, whether this article which, it is said, is intended to protect religious freedom only so far as individuals are concerned, can be invoked in favour of an institution or Organisation ?

issues.text: whether a Math comes within the description of a religious denomination as provided for in article 26

anchor.surface_text: With regard to article 26, the contention is that a Math does not come within the description of a religious denomination as provided for in the article

anchor.surface_text: the argument that has been advanced is, that the contribution is in reality a tax and not a fee and consequently the State Legislature had no authority to enact a provision of this character.

issues.text: whether the provision for compulsory contribution made in section 76 comes within the mischief of article 27

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, the High Court has. held that the provision for compulsory contribution made in section 76 of the Act comes within the mischief of article 27 of the Constitution.

issues.text: whether the various specific sections of the Act (ss. 18,21,25(4),26,28,29,30(2),31,54,55(2),56,58(3),63-69,70(2-4),76,89,99) are ultra vires the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: To sum up, we hold that the following sections are ultra vires the State Legislature in so far as they relate to this Math and what we say will also equally apply to other Maths of a similar nature. The sections of the new Act are sections 18, 209 21, 25 4 , section 26  to the extent section 25 4  is made applicable , section 28

arguments.claim: The law regulating the framing of a scheme interfering with the management of the Math and its affairs by the Mathadhipati conflicted with articles 19(1)(f) and 26 of the Constitution and was hence void under article 13

anchor.surface_text: The main contention, however, was that having regard to the fundamental rights guaranteed under the Constitution in matters of religion and religious institutions belonging to particular religious denominations, the law regulating the framing of a scheme interfering with the management of the Math and its affairs by the Mathadhipati conflicted with the provisions of art- icles 19 1   f  and 26 of the Constitution and was hence void under article 13.

arguments.court_reasoning: Some sections violate fundamental rights under Arts 19(1)(f), 25, 26; others valid as reasonable restrictions

arguments.claim: The provisions of the Act were discriminatory in their character and offended against article 15 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged further that the provisions of the Act were discriminatory in their character and offended against article 15 of the Constitution.

arguments.claim: The respondent as Mathadhipati has a right to property in the legal sense in the religious institution and its endowments which would enable him to claim the protection of article 19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: As regards article 19 1 f of the Constitution, the question that requires consideration is, whether the respondent as Mathadhipati has a right to property in the legal sense,, in the religious institution and its endowments which would enable him to claim the -protection of this article ?

anchor.surface_text: A question is also formulated as to whether this article deals with concrete rights of property at all ?

arguments.court_reasoning: Proceed on footing that Art 19(1)(f) applies to concrete as well as abstract rights

arguments.claim: Article 25 protects religious freedom only for individuals, not institutions

anchor.surface_text: So far as article 25 of the Constitution is concerned, the point raised is, whether this article which, it is said, is intended to protect religious freedom only so far as individuals are concerned, can be invoked in favour of an institution or Organisation ?

arguments.court_reasoning: Mathadhipati as individual head can invoke; institutions propagate through persons

arguments.claim: A Math does not come within the description of a religious denomination under article 26

anchor.surface_text: With regard to article 26, the contention is that a Math does not come within the description of a religious denomination as provided for in the article

arguments.court_reasoning: Math constitutes religious denomination or section thereof; followers of Madhwacharya

arguments.claim: Scope of Art 26(b): management only in matters of religion strictly, not secular activities

anchor.surface_text: what is the scope of clause  b  of the article which speaks of management of its own affairs in matters of religion ?

arguments.court_reasoning: Matters of religion include essential rituals; secular administration regulable

arguments.claim: Contribution under section 76 is a tax, beyond state competence

anchor.surface_text: the argument that has been advanced is, that the contribution is in reality a tax and not a fee and consequently the State Legislature had no authority to enact a provision of this character.

arguments.court_reasoning: It is a fee for services with quid pro quo

anchor.surface_text: Lastly, the High Court has. held that the provision for compulsory contribution made in section 76 of the Act comes within the mischief of article 27 of the Constitution.

arguments.court_reasoning: Fee not tax specifically appropriated for religion

arguments.claim: Mathadhipati holds beneficial property interest protected under Art 19(1)(f)

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other.

arguments.claim: Several specific sections (18,21,25(4), etc.) ultra vires as conflict with fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: To sum up, we hold that the following sections are ultra vires the State Legislature in so far as they relate to this Math and what we say will also equally apply to other Maths of a similar nature. The sections of the new Act are sections 18, 209 21, 25 4 , section 26  to the extent section 25 4  is made applicable , section 28

arguments.claim: Section 76 is a fee, not tax, within state competence
arguments.court_reasoning: Fee for services rendered by govt officers; quid pro quo exists

arguments.claim: Art 19(1)(f) only abstract rights, not concrete property rights

anchor.surface_text: A point was suggested by the learned AttorneyGeneral that as article 19 1   f  deals only with the natural rights inherent in a citizen to acquire, hold and dispose of property in the abstract without reference to rights to any particular property, it can be of no real assistance to the respondent in the present case

arguments.court_reasoning: Prefer to proceed on footing it applies to concrete rights; no full arguments
Unrestricted entry interferes with Arts 25,26; no safeguards for times, notice; s91 does not save

arguments.claim: Mathadhipati not mere trustee but has proprietary interest like shebait

anchor.surface_text: It was held by a Full Bench of the Calcutta High Court 2 , that Shebaitship. itself is property, and this decision was approved of by the Judicial Committee in Ganesh v Lal Behary 3 , and again in Bhabatarini v. Ashalata 4 .

holdings.text: The Mathadhipati holds a beneficial interest in the Math property which is protected under Article 19(1)(f) of the Constitution as the elements of office and property are blended together.

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other. The personal or beneficial interest of the Mahant in the endowments attached to an institution is manifested in his large powers of disposal and administration and his right to create derivative tenures in respect to endowed properties and these and other rights of a similar character invest the office of the Mahant with .the character of proprietary right which, though anomalous to some extent, is still a genuine legal right.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Drawing analogy from shebaitship precedents approved by Privy Council and this Court; property rights inherent in Mahantship beyond mere trusteeship.

holdings.text: Article 19(1)(f) applies to concrete as well as abstract rights of property.

anchor.surface_text: We would prefer to proceed, as this Court has proceeded all along, in dealing with similar cases in the past, on the footing that article 19 1   f  applies equally to concrete as well as abstract rights of property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No full arguments heard; proceed on prior practice without deciding definitively.

holdings.text: The Mathadhipati can invoke Article 25 as an individual head of spiritual fraternity to practise and propagate religion.

anchor.surface_text: A Mathadhipati is certainly not a corporate body he is the head of a spiritual fraternity and by virtue of his office has to perform the duties of a religious teacher. it is his duty to practise and propagate the religious tenets, of which he is an adherent and if any provision of law prevents him from propagating his doctrines, that would certainly affect the religious freedom which is guaranteed to every person under article 25.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Article protects acts done in pursuance of religion by persons; institutions act through individuals.

holdings.text: Shirur Math constitutes a religious denomination or section thereof under Article 26.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court has found that the Math in question is really an institution belonging to Sivalli Brahmins, who are a section of the followers of Madhwacharya and hence constitutes a religious denomination within the meaning of article 26 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Definition includes collection with common faith, organization, name; Udipi Maths founded by Madhwacharya for his followers.

holdings.text: Under Article 26(b), religious denominations have autonomy in essential rites and ceremonies regarded as integral to religion; secular/economic activities associated therewith are regulable by State.

anchor.surface_text: what is the scope of clause  b  of the article which speaks of management of its own affairs in matters of religion ?

holdings.reasoning_summary: Matters of religion determined by doctrines of the religion; Art 25(2)(a) allows regulation of secular activities; illustrated by rituals vs economic aspects; foreign precedents on Jehovah's Witnesses.

holdings.text: Section 21 of the 1951 Act is ultra vires as it permits unrestricted entry interfering with Articles 25 and 26 rights.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No safeguards for time, notice, sacred areas; Section 91 does not save as it excludes express provisions and undefined customs.

holdings.text: Sections 30(2) and 31 of the 1951 Act impose unreasonable restrictions on Mathadhipati's property rights under Article 19(1)(f).

anchor.surface_text: We think that sections 30 2  and 31 have been rightly held to be invalid by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Fetters discretion over surplus funds for beneficial purposes like propagation; impairs dignity and efficiency.

holdings.text: Sections 55, 56 of the 1951 Act are invalid as they encroach on proprietary and management rights under Articles 19(1)(f) and 26(d).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Restricts personal gifts (Pathakanikas); allows arbitrary manager appointment without mismanagement precondition, reducing Mahant to servant.

holdings.text: Sections 63 to 69 (Chapter VI) of the 1951 Act are void as drastically taking over administration without court access.

anchor.surface_text: We hold therefore, in agreement with High Court that these sections should. be hold to be void.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No judicial remedy against notification vesting administration in executive officer.

holdings.text: Section 76 contribution is a valid fee for services rendered, not a tax beyond State competence nor violating Article 27.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Fee has quid pro quo (services by govt officers); distinct from tax for general revenue; not specifically for promoting religion.

holdings.text: The High Court writ of prohibition stands as appellant confined to constitutional points and did not challenge merits.

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we might arrive at on the constitutional points raised before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appeal under Art 132(1) limited to constitutional issues; merits findings not canvassed.

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order issuing writ of prohibition upheld as merits not challenged; Commissioner prohibited from proceeding with scheme for Shirur Math; several sections of Madras Hindu Religious and Charitable Endowments Act, 1951 held ultra vires (e.g., ss. 21, 30(2), 31, 55, 56, Ch. VI ss. 63-69), others valid
directions: Prohibition against proceeding with framing of scheme stands
Section 76 valid as fee not tax

anchor.surface_text: Thus in the conception of Mahantship, as in Shebaitship, both the elements of office and property, of duties and personal interest are blended together and neither can be detached from the other. The personal or beneficial interest of the Mahant in the endowments attached to an institution is manifested in his large powers of disposal and administration and his right to create derivative tenures in respect to endowed properties and these and other rights of a similar character invest the office of the Mahant with .the character of proprietary right which, though anomalous to some extent, is still a genuine legal right.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we light arrive at on the constitutional points raised bef

anchor.surface_text: The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we light arrive at on the constitutional points raised bef

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we light arrive at on the constitutional points raised bef

We would prefer to proceed, as this Court has proceeded all along, in dealing with similar cases in the past, on the footing that article 19 1   f  applies equally to concrete as well as abstract rights of property.

A Mathadhipati is certainly not a corporate body he is the head of a spiritual fraternity and by virtue of his office has to perform the duties of a religious teacher. it is his duty to practise and propagate the religious tenets, of which he is an adherent and if any provision of law prevents him from propagating his doctrines, that would certainly affect the religious freedom which is guaranteed to every person under article 25.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we light arrive at on the constitutional points raised bef

The High Court has found that the Math in question is really an institution belonging to Sivalli Brahmins, who are a section of the followers of Madhwacharya and hence constitutes a religious denomination within the meaning of article 26 of the Constitution.

The position, therefore, is that the order of the High Court issuing the writ of prohibition against the appellant must stand irrespective of the decision which we light arrive at on the constitutional points raised bef
